subject: Re: [junit] Global Rule, active for all tests
msgSnippet: Hi David, Some examples: * Custom reporting (bumblebee is one example of this) * Metrics (especially timing) * Dependency injection into test cases These are
messageBody:
Hi David,

Some examples:
* Custom reporting (bumblebee is one example of this)
* Metrics (especially timing)
* Dependency injection into test cases

These are generally achievable in other ways, like in that bumblebee uses
Suites and parses the strings from the test structure.

However, if these "aspects" were addressed in this more generic "ruly" way,
I sense that such a JUnit API would separate the JUnit implementation from
the extensions, much like the Rules does today.

Did that compile?

Cheers
Daniel


On Mon, Dec 14, 2009 at 3:43 PM, David Saff <david@...> wrote:

>
>
> I'd like to talk about concrete applications one by one--we pushed
> hard on method rules because it was so easy to write about 10 useful
> rules once we were done, and having those useful rules pushed us
> toward a satisfying design. Once the concrete examples are in hand,
> we can look at how to generalize.
>
> In Bogdan's original case, a RunListener was sufficient. I definitely
> think that bumblebee is a very interesting use case. What are the
> others?
>
> David
>
>
> On Sun, Dec 13, 2009 at 8:58 AM, Joakim Ohlrogge
> <joakim.ohlrogge@... <joakim.ohlrogge%40gmail.com>> wrote:
> > I think that it would address a crosscutting concern of the run. Pretty
> much
> > like aspects work. This way you could enrich the test-run by
> declaratively
> > hooking into the execution. Having global rules you could for instance,
> > given a match-criteria selects points in the run to hook into.
> >
> > How about "declaratively enhance" as a meaning?
> >
> > Whatever implementation you choose I have the following wishes based on
> > working with bumblebee and trying to do these kind of global
> enhancements:
> >
> > * That I do not /have to/ run the tests via a specific suite to have my
> > global rules applied. The reason is that it's sometimes desirable to run
> > only one test and it would be nice if that test is enhanced in the same
> way
> > it would be if run via the suite.
> >
> > * That I would not have to add anymore information than can be found on
> the
> > class path. The reason is that needing specific configuration such as
> system
> > properties or environment variables would make my tests harder to run.
> >
> > I have often wanted to make this kind of global rules and I think that
> > having the possibility would open up for a host of new ways to creatively
> > enhance JUnit. Tools such as bumblebee being one of many things that
> would
> > be simple to do given such a feature. I hooked into a suite to capture
> > System.out for bumblebee documentation and it works well given that I run
> > via that suite. If I don't run via that suite I have experienced hard to
> > debug problems.
> >

> >> > Bogdan,

> >> > Just this week, we were discussing a similar issue with global rules,
> >> > inspired partly by Daniel's patch, so further votes would make a

> >> >
> >> > David Saff
> >> >
> >> > On Fri, Dec 4, 2009 at 10:34 AM, Bogdan
> >> > <bogdan.mocanu.notifications@...<bogdan.mocanu.notifications%40gmail.com>>
> wrote:
> >> > > Hi everyone,
> >> > >
> >> > > as we have it currently, we can place a Rule in a test, and that
> rule
> >> will be activated for that test. To have the rule working in several
> tests,
> >> you have to place the Rule in each test.
> >> > >
> >> > > However, I am searching for a way to activate a Rule for all the
> tests
> >> that are executed, without needing to add the rule to each test. Perhaps
> by
> >> specifying a Java property parameter when running the tests (I could
> also
> >> set this as a global Java option, therefore being used upon each
> execution
> >> of the JVM).
> >> > >
> >> > > Do you know if this is possible?
> >> > >
> >> > > The reason why I need this, is: I am making the plans and gathering
> the
> >> ideas for creating a simple Swing application that will display the
> results
> >> of the executed tests (just like the JUnit view in
> Eclipse/Idea/Netbeans,
> >> but perhaps with more details, and also available for anyone, not just
> IDE
> >> users). Currently I developed a small agent rule, that you can place in
> your
> >> test, and it will report to the console the status of your tests (the
> Swing
> >> console runs remotely).
> >> > >
> >> > > This is ok, but it means that you will have to add this rule to each
> >> and every test that you have. It also means that will not be an easy
> task to
> >> disable this rule, if you don't want it anymore.
> >> > >
> >> > > Therefore a possibility to enable Rules globally for all tests I
> think
> >> is the best solution for my case, and also a good tool to have for
> various
> >> other tasks.
> >> > >
> >> > > What do you think? Also, what do you think about the Swing console
> >> idea?
> >> > >
> >> > > Cheers,
> >> > > Bogdan
